instruction: Who has rights, starboard or port?
output: When boats are on opposite tacks, the starboard-tack boat has right of way. The port-tack boat shall keep clear of the starboard-tack boat. (RRS 10)

instruction: What should I do if two boats are approaching on port and starboard tack?
input: I'm on port tack approaching the windward mark.
output: As the port tack boat, you must keep clear of the starboard tack boat. When boats are on opposite tacks, the port-tack boat shall keep clear of the starboard-tack boat (RRS 10). You should either tack or bear away early enough to keep clear.

instruction: What is the definition of 'keep clear'?
output: A boat keeps clear of a right-of-way boat if the right-of-way boat can sail her course with no need to take avoiding action and with no less than arm’s-length clearance. (RRS 11)

instruction: Define 'room to tack' and explain when a competitor may hail for it.
output: “Room to tack” is the space a boat needs to tack safely without immediately making contact. A competitor may hail “Room to tack” only when: 1) she is approaching an obstruction and will soon need to make a substantial course change to avoid it safely, and 2) she is sailing close-hauled or above. (RRS 20.1)

instruction: Explain the right-of-way rule when boats are on opposite tacks.
output: When boats are on opposite tacks, the port-tack boat shall keep clear of the starboard-tack boat. (RRS 10)

instruction: In a port/starboard situation approaching a windward mark, who must give room?
input: I'm on port tack approaching the windward mark. A starboard tack boat is also approaching the mark on a collision course.
output: You are on port tack and must keep clear of the starboard-tack boat. When boats are on opposite tacks, the port-tack boat shall keep clear of the starboard-tack boat. (RRS 10) Mark-Room rules (RRS 18) do not apply between opposite-tack boats on a beat to windward.

instruction: When must a protest flag be displayed by a protesting boat?
output: A protesting boat shall hail “Protest” and conspicuously display a red flag at the first reasonable opportunity after the incident if her hull length is longer than 6 m. (RRS 60.2(a)(1))

instruction: Describe the changes in signaling for protests in the 2025-2028 rules.
output: Under RRS 60.2, if the protestee is beyond hailing distance or the incident was an error in sailing the course, the only requirement is to inform the protestee at the first reasonable opportunity—displaying a flag or hail is not required. (RRS 60.2(b))

instruction: What is the new timing requirement for delivering a protest under RRS 2025?
output: A protest must be delivered in writing within two hours after the last boat in the race finishes, or two hours after the relevant information is available, whichever is later, unless the sailing instructions specify otherwise. (RRS 60.3(b))

instruction: Explain the concept of 'mark-room'.
output: Mark-Room is the space a boat needs to sail her proper course to round or pass the mark on the required side and to leave it astern. (RRS 18.1)

instruction: How does Rule 18.2 allocate mark-room between overlapped boats entering the zone?
output: When the first of two boats reaches the zone: if they are overlapped, the outside boat at that moment shall give the inside boat mark-room; if not overlapped, the boat clear astern at that moment shall give mark-room. (RRS 18.2(a))

instruction: What happens if a boat is forced to break a rule of Part 2 while sailing within her mark-room?
output: A boat sailing within the mark-room to which she is entitled is exonerated for breaking a rule of Section A of Part 2, rule 15, 16, or 31 if the incident was caused by the other boat’s failure to give her mark-room. (RRS 43.1(b))

instruction: Define 'proper course' and its implications.
output: Proper Course is the course a boat would choose to sail the course as quickly as possible in the absence of other boats. A boat is not sailing her proper course when taking a penalty. (RRS 2 defn; RRS 2)

instruction: Explain the difference between an obstruction and a continuing obstruction.
output: An obstruction is an object a boat cannot pass without changing course substantially. A continuing obstruction is one that the boat nearer would pass alongside for at least three of her hull lengths. (RRS 19 defns)

instruction: What are the requirements for taking a Two-Turns Penalty?
output: After getting well clear of other boats, a boat takes a Two-Turns Penalty by promptly making two full turns in the same direction, each including one tack and one gybe. At the finish, she must be completely on the course side before finishing. (RRS 44.2)

instruction: When is a One-Turn Penalty permitted instead of Two-Turns?
output: A boat may take a One-Turn Penalty when she may have broken rule 31 (touching a mark). Alternatively, the notice of race may specify a Scoring Penalty in place of One-Turn. (RRS 44.1)

instruction: How does a Scoring Penalty modify a boat’s score?
output: A boat takes a Scoring Penalty by displaying a yellow flag and informing the race committee; her score is worsened by the number of points stated in the sailing instructions (20% of DNF if unspecified), without changing others’ scores. (RRS 44.3)

instruction: What actions are permitted under Rule 42 exceptions?
output: A boat may roll to facilitate steering; exaggerate rolling during a tack/gybe without extra speed; pump once per wave when planing; scull when stationary above close-hauled; scull to initiate foiling; reduce speed by moving the helm. (RRS 42.3)

instruction: Define 'finish' and conditions that invalidate a finish.
output: A boat finishes when any part of her hull crosses the finishing line from the course side after her starting signal. She has not finished if she takes a penalty, corrects a course error, or continues racing beyond the line until she clears. (RRS 28.1)

instruction: What is the general recall signal and procedure?
output: General recall is signalled by First Substitute flag with two sounds. The warning signal for the new start is made one minute after First Substitute is removed. (RRS 29.2)

instruction: Explain the requirements for a boat to hail and display a protest if the other boat is beyond hailing distance.
output: If the protestee is beyond hailing distance at the incident time, the protestor need only inform the protestee of her intention at the first reasonable opportunity; neither hail nor flag display is required. (RRS 60.2(b)(1))

instruction: How has Rule 76.1 changed regarding exclusion of boats?
output: RRS 76.1 now requires the organizing authority to reject or cancel an entry before the first race after receipt of entry and to state a proper reason, provided in writing if requested. (RRS 76.1)

instruction: What is the penalty for breaking rule 30.2 in a windsurfing fleet race?
output: In windsurfing fleet racing, breaking rule 30.2 (the Z-flag 20% Scoring Penalty) incurs a 20% Scoring Penalty applied without a hearing, unless the heat is abandoned or postponed. (Windsurfing Appendix B)

instruction: Describe the changes to protest contents requirements in 2025 rules.
output: RRS 60.3(a) now requires a delivered protest to identify only the protestor, protestee and incident; other details must be delivered promptly upon delivery but may be added later before hearing. (RRS 60.3(a))

instruction: In match racing, how is a penalty signalled by an umpire?
output: An umpire signals a penalty by displaying a red flag with one long sound and hailing or signalling the penalised boat’s sail number. (Match Racing Appendix C, rule C5.2)

instruction: What is the 'last point of certainty' in match racing umpiring?
output: The 'last point of certainty' means umpires assume the boats’ state or relationship remains until they are certain it has changed, avoiding judgments based on unclear transitions. (Match Racing Appendix C, rule 7)

instruction: How does a matching series score a tie between teams?
output: In team racing round-robins, tied teams are separated by number of race wins; if incomplete (<80% sailed), results voided, then tie breaks by head-to-head records. (Team Racing Appendix D)

instruction: When must a windsurfing competitor have their sail out of the water?
output: In the final minute before her start signal, a board’s sail must be out of the water and in normal position, except when accidentally capsized. (Windsurfing Appendix B, rule 23.3)

instruction: What changes apply to rule 42 for windsurfing fleet racing?
output: 'Pumping and fanning the sail is permitted. Paddling, swimming, or walking to propel the board is prohibited.' (Windsurfing Appendix B, rule 42)

instruction: Explain the rights of protest committees under rule 60.4(c).
output: The protest committee may protest a boat if it learns of an incident causing damage or injury—even without a protest from another boat. (RRS 60.4(c)(1))

instruction: How are postponement signals altered in match racing?
output: In match racing, 'AP' flag procedures change timing: the attention signal is made one minute after removal unless the race is postponed or abandoned again. (Match Racing Appendix C)

instruction: Define 'continuing obstruction' and give an example.
output: A continuing obstruction is one a boat nearer to it would pass alongside for at least three hull lengths—for example, a navigation buoy in a narrow channel. (RRS 19 defn)

instruction: What is the standard of proof at misconduct hearings?
output: Misconduct hearings use the 'comfortable satisfaction' standard, mindful of seriousness, unless national law requires otherwise. (RRS 69.2(g))

instruction: When may a race committee change the course after the start?
output: After the start, for safety or fairness, the race committee may shorten (flag S) or abandon (flag N) the race, or change the next leg by flag C with sound and compass/shape signals. (RRS 32 & 33)

instruction: What defines 'abandon' versus 'postpone'?
output: Abandon (flag N) voids a race but may be resailed; postpone (flag AP) delays the start for later. (RRS 32.3 & 25.3)

instruction: Explain how discretionary penalties work.
output: When a boat reports a breach subject to a DP, the protest committee may impose a penalty ranging up to disqualification without a hearing, based on evidence. (RRS 64)

instruction: Describe the new rule for taking penalty at marks in match racing.
output: In match racing, Rule 18.3(b) limits how far from the mark an inside overlapped right-of-way boat may sail before tacking: no farther than needed to sail her proper course. (Appendix C)

instruction: How is an Individual Recall protested in match racing?
output: If on the course side at her start, the race committee hails 'Recall' and the boat’s sail number, rather than using flag X. (Appendix C, rule 29.1)

instruction: What changes were made to rule 76.3 for redress requests?
output: RRS 76.3 now allows redress requests for improper rejection/exclusion and for breaking RRS 76.2. (76.3)

instruction: Define 'room' and its factors.
output: Room is the space a boat needs in current conditions, including room to comply with Part 2 and Rule 31 while manoeuvring promptly in a seamanlike way. (RRS defn)

instruction: Explain the new timing for redress requests in 2025 rules.
output: Redress requests must be delivered as soon as reasonably possible after relevant information is available, replacing ‘after learning of reasons’. (RRS 61.2(b))

instruction: How are capsized boats treated under rule 22?
output: If possible, boats shall avoid a capsized boat. A capsized boat shall not interfere with others. (RRS 22)

instruction: When is a black flag disqualification not excludable?
output: A black-flag DQ under rule 30.4 cannot be excluded in series scoring and applies even if the race is restarted or resailed. (RRS 30.4)

instruction: What are the revisions to Protest Committee structure in 2025?
output: Part 5 Sections A & B have been rearranged: Protests & Redress are rules 60–62 and Hearings & Decisions are rules 63–65, improving organization. (RRS intro)

instruction: How has redress timing changed for requests other than the last day?
output: RRS 61.2(b)(3) now requires other redress requests 'as soon as reasonably possible after the relevant information is available.'

instruction: Describe the new rule on penalties without hearing for prescribed penalties.
output: RRS 60.5(b)(3) permits NoR/SI to prescribe penalties enforceable without a hearing under rules that expressly allow it. (RRS 60.5)

instruction: In team racing, what penalty is imposed for an unpenalized Part 2 breach causing contact?

instruction: When can a boat be exonerated for breaking rule 14?
output: A right-of-way boat or one sailing within her room or mark-room is exonerated for breaking rule 14 if the contact causes no damage or injury. (RRS 43.1(c))

instruction: Explain the new post-race penalty preamble note.

instruction: What is the minimum number of races for a series under windsurfing rules?

instruction: How is a match racing heat started?
output: Match heats start with a 7-minute sequence: 7′ attention (flag F), 5′ warning (pennant), 4′ preparatory (P), 2′ pre-start exit (blue/yellow), then start signal at 0. (Appendix C)

instruction: Define 'party to a hearing' in protests.
output: A party includes protestor, protestee, boats requesting redress, those for which redress is considered, persons alleged under rule 69, and support persons in hearings. (RRS defn)

instruction: Explain how race ties are scored under low-point system.
output: Tied boats share points by averaging the points for the tied places. (RRS A7)

instruction: What is the obligation under Rule 3?

instruction: When may a race be abandoned by the committee?
output: After the start, the committee may abandon for foul weather, insufficient wind, a missing mark, or safety/fairness reasons, signalling flag N with three sounds. (RRS 32.3)

instruction: Define 'retired after finishing' and its scoring effect.

instruction: How are excludable and non-excludable DQs identified in scoring?

instruction: What is the process for reopening a hearing on new evidence?

instruction: Describe the major change to Part 5 numbering effective 2025.
